title: If I go into a chapter 13, how does confirming the plan work? Do all creditors have to agree? Please give me Ch13 highlights
question: I am considering filing 13 and will certainly use an attorney to do so, but am wondering if I could get a little explanation or a link on how the process typically goes down.
question_tags: Child support,Bankruptcy,Bankruptcy court,Chapter 13 bankruptcy,Debt,Secured debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Chapter 13 bankruptcy reorganization plan,General Practice
answers:
As someone who completes these plans on a daily basis I would not recommend doing a chapter 13 plan on your own. Weekly at the bankruptcy court I see people who are attempting do get there chapter 13 plan approved who have done them without an attorney only to be dismissed. There are allot of technical issues that need to be addressed and completed accurately. When you are talking about your financial future, your home or your car you really need to gets some professional help.

While I agree with Mr. Araujo's comments, I strongly recommend that you consider retaining a qualifieid bankruptcy attorney in your area if your proposed plan involves cramming down vehicle loans or stripping second mortgages. Most chapter 13 bankruptcy attorneys will accept a modest fee upfront with the remainder of their fee paid in the chapter 13 plan. Your plan payment does not increase if the attorney is paid in the plan. The attorney is treated as an administrative creditor and it reduces the amount available for distribution to the unsecured creditors. If you fail to properly treat your creditors in the chapter 13 plan, you can expect objections from the chapter 13 trustee as well as your creditors.

Additionally, most bankruptcy attorneys offer a free consultation, so there is really nothing to loose if you meet with one.

The confirmation process is pretty simple. You plan must be feasible and you must commit all of your disposable income. If you are an above median income household in your state for your size it gets a little more complicated, but not much.

The are many rules regarding debt that must be followed in your plan. All secured debt arrears for property you are going to keep has to be paid. All taxes, child support and other kinds of debts must be paid.

You cannot discriminate against the class of unsecured creditors by favoring one over another.

You must list all property and income and expenses. Just sit tight and if the Trustee or a creditor objects it will be resolved. Objections are not unusual.
